Happy Mother's Day to my beautiful, inspiring and selfless mom. If I'm half the mother you are someday then my kids will be very lucky. ❤ I love you. #mothersday #inch

Sunday was a great day at the MCI marathon on Inch beach. It was my 1st event as a race director, also it was Ireland's 1st and only full marathon on the beach I'm sure there cannot be too many in the world???. Some struggled on sand while others loved it and went on to achieve PR's/PB's. I ran just over 21miles setting up and sweeping the course. Only downside was I got my car stuck in the sand got it out eventually.

It's #markupmonday and time for yet another educational boxwood rule post from yours truly...yay? 😶 This rule, a No. 70-1/4 from the Chapin-Stephens Company (1901-29) of Pine Meadow, Connecticut is an odd one. First off, this rule doesn't have a direct, correlating model under the historical King of rule companies in the United States, the Stanley Rule & Level Company. This three-foot, four-fold, with square main joint, middle plates at the knuckle joints, and in a 'broad' configuration (meaning it's wider than the standard width), seems to be limited to H. Chapin from the 1850s to 1901 (as a No. 23-1/2), at which time the model was carried forward to the joint company after merging with D.H. Stephens & Company of Riverton, CT, as the 70-1/4. [note: There is an uncommon Stanley No. 170BE of similar configuration, but it had painted on "blindman's" markings and numerals, so I do not consider it a direct model correlation.] Secondly, what makes this fairly uncommon rule even more interesting, is that this particular example was ordered from the Chapin-Stephens factory with a special request for the exterior scales to be in Spanish inches instead of the standard imperial inches. Swiping left to the second photo, you will note that the graduations on the exterior of the rule do not completely fill the length of the 36" rule, as the Spanish inch, AKA the Castile, was only a diminutive 0.91 imperial inch long. Thus, approximately three inches are lost over the folding rule's imperial three feet of overall length. To have a rule, that is quite an uncommon model in the first place, be manufactured with a special order scale of limited use in the US, means that it is far more uncommon, and may possibly be a one-of-a-kind special order tool. Now, this doesn't likely translate to massive value, because the extremely small group of rule aficionados on this planet don't necessarily wield enough buying power, influence, and geekitude to make such a rule highly coveted in collecting circles. In fact, as the only bidder on this item when I bought it, I suspect most tool collectors would simply dismiss it as a novelty. 🤓

💘इतना👉🏻 Attitude👈🏻 किसे दिखाति है पगली,😎
जितने #Inch# की तेरी कमर है उतनी तो तेरे बाबू की 😉Ex gf’s😉है.💟
